variant.question: A pilot needs to announce the wake turbulence category to the ATS unit:

options.text: If the MTOM exceeds 136 000 kg, upon every initial call on a new frequency.
If the actual TOM of the aircraft exceeds 7000 kg, upon every initial call on a new frequency.
Only upon first contact of an approach, departure or tower frequency, if the aircraft belongs to the category 'heavy' or 'super'.
When flying in congested airspace where separation is critical, all aircraft must append the wake turbulence to their call sign.

variant.question: When air-ground data link is used, automated routine observations should be made (reports of air temperature, wind and turbulence). What is correct about aircraft not equipped with air-ground data link equipment?

options.text: They are only required to make reports upon passing reporting points, not more than 30 minutes every time.
They are required to make regular reports, regardless of position.
They are only required to report once, immediately after being requested.
They shall be exempt from making regular reports, unless specifically requested by ATC.

options.text: ...RIGHT TURN. CONTINUING VFR FOR LANDING RWY 09\. NEXT REPORT FINAL."
...RIGHT TURN MAINTAINING 4000 FT. NEXT REPORT AT TIME 1201\. ALL STATIONS RADIO CHECK."

...RIGHT TURN HEADING 270 MAINTAINING 4000 FT. CONTINUING VFR FOR LANDING RWY 09."

options.text: "JOIN DOWNWIND RUNWAY 05, F-SN"
"JOIN RIGHT HAND DOWNWIND RUNWAY 05 HEIGHT 1000 FEET QFE 1002, F-SN"
"JOIN RIGHT HAND DOWNWIND RUNWAY 05 ALTITUDE 1000 FEET QFE 1002, F-SN"

variant.question: ATC instruct you: "G-ACZG, TURN RIGHT IMMEDIATELY SIXTY DEGREES TO AVOID TRAFFIC ELEVEN OCLOCK FOUR MILES." What do you do?

options.text: Start a standard rate turn right onto the new heading immediately, and acknowledge the instruction when time permits.
Look for the traffic, and when you have seen it, acknowledge and turn right onto the new heading.
Acknowledge the instruction then check visually that it is safe to turn before starting a turn right onto the new heading.
Immediately select the maximum angle of bank possible and pull back to make the 60-degree turn as rapidly as possible.

variant.question: What elements form the call sign of a ground station?

options.text: The location, followed by a suffix (eg 118.725) that ensures different ground stations at the same location can be distinguished.

Depending on the rules of the State where the station is located, the elements may include a prefix for the frequency (eg 118.725), its location, and a suffix (e.g. RADAR)) indicating the type of service being provided.
The location, followed by a suffix (eg DELIVERY) indicating the type of service being provided by that station.
A prefix (e.g. GROUND) indicating the type of service being provided, followed by the name of the station's location.

ZERO NINE ZERO ONE ZERO BIERFELD.
BIERFELD TEN MILES ZERO NINE ZERO.
POSITION TEN MILES WEST OF BIERFELD.

variant.question: You are Pilot-In-Command of a scheduled international commercial air transport flight, flying at FL140\. Your aircraft is equipped with all the necessary communication and navigation equipment. After 30 minutes of flight at cruising altitude, you notice the unserviceability of the air-ground data link. options.text: You should attempt to re-start the data link system so that routine meteorological observations can be sent. If this remains unserviceable, a special transponder code should be selected.
The routine meteorological observations that are normally transmitted every 15 minutes should now be sent via voice communications.

Because the data link is unserviceable, a special meteorological observation should be transmitted via voice communications.

D-EENE, SELCAL received.

variant.question:
A change of frequency shall generally be authorized by the ground station. On which occasions can a pilot make a change of frequency without authorization from the station?

1\. When he/she thinks it is useful to realize approach and landing   
 2\. When he/she asks the tower to change the frequency by necessity   
 3\. In distress

At the Tenerif’s Accident of 1977 two aircraft collided when one aircraft started the take off run while the other was taxiing onto the runway (taxiway was occupied). The aircraft taking off reported, “we are now at take-off”, and the tower replied “OK…, stand by for take-off. I will call you”. Simultaneously, the other aircraft taxiing onto the runway reported, “ah…hu..we are still taxiing down the runway”. What is the reason these last two transmissions might NOT have reached the take-off aircraft?

options.text: A technical reason is NOT to be suspected. Most likely, the crew was absorbed by the takeoff and probably failed to notice the calls.
If neither of the two messages was received, there must have been a failure of the receiver of the aircraft taking off. There is NO other possible explanation.
The message of the Tower must have been received. The transmissions of ground stations have a general priority to supersede other simultaneous transmissions.
As simultaneous transmissions on one frequency are NOT possible, they can block each other out. NOTHING or just interference noises might have been heard instead.

ROGER
STANDBY

variant.question: How shall a pilot ask the ATC for the QFE?

options.text: request Quebec Fox Echo
request QFE.
request Quebec Fox Easy
request Queen Fox Easy

variant.question: A Pilot wants to contact frequency 118.0333 MHz, but selects 118.035\. The frequency spacing is:

options.text: 25 kHz
8.33 kHz
8.35 kHz

variant.question: Which of the following occurences during the Approach and Landing phases of flight must be reported to ATC?

options.text: Light icing experienced on approach.
Braking action worse than reported.
Visibility seems lower than reported.
Low drifting snow on the runway.

variant.question: An aircraft is in radio contact with Murdoch Approach. The controller wants the pilot to change frequency, establish communication and continue under the control of Murdoch Radar. Which instruction would the pilot expect to hear?

options.text: Recleared Murdoch Radar on 134.870.
Monitor Murdoch Radar on 134.870.
Report Murdoch Radar on 134.870.
Contact Murdoch Radar on 134.870.

variant.question: When all runways at an airport are affected by wind shear, how is it reported on a METAR?

options.text: WS ALL RWY + ICAO Airport Code
WS ALL RWY
WS + Runway Designator for each runway
This information is not reported

variant.question:
Complete the following statement:

An Air Traffic Control Unit…

options.text: May not ask an aircraft to change its call sign after accepting the flight plan.
May instruct an aircraft to temporarily change its call sign for safety reasons when there is a risk of confusion between two or more similar call signs.
May require to change the call sign for safety reasons when there is a risk of confusion between two or more similar call signs providing the aircraft is on a repetitive flight plan.
Must not ask an aircraft to change its call sign.
